DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Cold Snap Won't Abate
Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to tighten; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `It might ...'
DOC.TEXT: It was colder in Oklahoma than in Alaska today as a deep chill continued to grip most of the nation before winter's official start. Snow and sleet pelted the Deep South and freezing temperatures extended to the Gulf Coast. The cold snap has chilled much of nation for the past several days, and forecasters said there was no end in sight. ``It might not be that unusual if it was the middle of January ... but everyone agrees this is indeed atypical,'' said weather service meteorologist Edward Yandrich in New York. ``In layman's terms, it's just been very, very cold.'' Temperatures this morning were below zero in the Upper Plains, in the teens in the Rockies and in the 20s along the Texas Panhandle. At 3 a.m. EST it was 20 degrees in Oklahoma City and 27 and snowing in Anchorage, Alaska. Light snow fell Sunday afternoon in Houston, Texas, while parts of upstate New York got 3-4 inches and snow fell in northern Maine, the Upper Plains, parts of Iowa, Minnesota, the Dakotas and the Rockies. Today, sleet or freezing rain fell in Atlanta, Charleston, S.C., and Macon, Ga., and snow was expected from northern Texas through Alabama. That storm was expected to reach South Carolina late today, and in the Washington, D.C., area by Tuesday night. Record low temperatures were recorded in many cities. Records were set shortly after midnight today in Cleveland, at minus 3 degrees, and Columbus, Ohio, at minus 4; on Sunday, records fell in at least 19 cities, including Elkins, W.Va., at minus 8, and Paducah, Ky., and Indianapolis, minus 10. The National Weather Service warned of frost likely near San Diego, Calif., tonight. High temperature for the Lower 48 states on Sunday was 80 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla., and Miami.
